vulnerability_findings.name: use-multiple-require
vulnerability_findings.message: Using multiple require statements is cheaper than using && multiple check combinations. There are more advantages, such as easier to read code and better coverage reports.

vulnerability_findings.name: arbitrary-send
vulnerability_findings.message:
RegistryExec.exec (RegistryExec.sol#282-311) sends eth to arbitrary user
	Dangerous calls:
	- address(msg.sender).transfer(address(this).balance) (RegistryExec.sol#300)
	- address(msg.sender).transfer(address(this).balance) (RegistryExec.sol#310)

vulnerability_findings.name: shadowing-state
vulnerability_findings.message:
RegistryExec.EXEC_SEL (RegistryExec.sol#273) shadows:
	- ScriptExec.EXEC_SEL (RegistryExec.sol#93)

vulnerability_findings.name: constant-function
vulnerability_findings.message: ScriptExec.getAction (RegistryExec.sol#107-112) is declared view but contains assembly code

vulnerability_findings.name: constant-function
vulnerability_findings.message: ScriptExec.checkReturn (RegistryExec.sol#138-152) is declared view but contains assembly code

vulnerability_findings.name: constant-function
vulnerability_findings.message: RegistryExec.getSelector (RegistryExec.sol#314-321) is declared view but contains assembly code

vulnerability_findings.name: reentrancy-no-eth
vulnerability_findings.message:
Reentrancy in RegistryExec.updateAppInstance (RegistryExec.sol#415-457):
	External calls:
	- registry_idx = StorageInterface(app_storage).getIndex(inst.current_registry_exec_id) (RegistryExec.sol#446)
	- latest_version = RegistryInterface(registry_idx).getLatestVersion(app_storage,inst.current_registry_exec_id,inst.current_provider,inst.app_name) (RegistryExec.sol#447-452)
	State variables written after the call(s):
	- instance_info (RegistryExec.sol#456)

vulnerability_findings.name: reentrancy-benign
vulnerability_findings.message:
Reentrancy in ScriptExec.createAppInstance (RegistryExec.sol#164-179):
	External calls:
	- (exec_id,version) = StorageInterface(app_storage).createInstance(msg.sender,_app_name,provider,registry_exec_id,_init_calldata) (RegistryExec.sol#166-168)
	State variables written after the call(s):
	- app_instances (RegistryExec.sol#171)
	- deployed_by (RegistryExec.sol#170)
	- deployed_instances (RegistryExec.sol#176)
	- instance_info (RegistryExec.sol#175)

vulnerability_findings.name: reentrancy-benign
vulnerability_findings.message:
Reentrancy in RegistryExec.createRegistryInstance (RegistryExec.sol#331-354):
	External calls:
	- exec_id = StorageInterface(app_storage).createRegistry(_index,_implementation) (RegistryExec.sol#336)
	State variables written after the call(s):
	- deployed_by (RegistryExec.sol#349)
	- deployed_registry_instances (RegistryExec.sol#351)
	- registry_exec_id (RegistryExec.sol#343)
	- registry_instance_info (RegistryExec.sol#350)

vulnerability_findings.name: assembly
vulnerability_findings.message:
ScriptExec.getAction uses assembly (RegistryExec.sol#107-112)
	- RegistryExec.sol#108-112

vulnerability_findings.message:
ScriptExec.checkErrors uses assembly (RegistryExec.sol#115-135)
	- RegistryExec.sol#119-131

vulnerability_findings.name: assembly
vulnerability_findings.message:
ScriptExec.checkReturn uses assembly (RegistryExec.sol#138-152)
	- RegistryExec.sol#140-151

vulnerability_findings.name: assembly
vulnerability_findings.message:
RegistryExec.getSelector uses assembly (RegistryExec.sol#314-321)
	- RegistryExec.sol#315-321

vulnerability_findings.vulnerability_code:
function getInstances(bytes32 _app_name) public view returns (bytes32[] memory) {

    return app_instances[_app_name];
vulnerability_findings.message: ScriptExec.getInstances (RegistryExec.sol#208-210) should be declared external

vulnerability_findings.vulnerability_code:
function getDeployedLength(address _deployer) public view returns (uint) {

    return deployed_instances[_deployer].length;
vulnerability_findings.message: ScriptExec.getDeployedLength (RegistryExec.sol#217-219) should be declared external

vulnerability_findings.name: solc-version
vulnerability_findings.message:
Detected issues with version pragma in RegistryExec.sol:
	- pragma solidity^0.4.23 (RegistryExec.sol#3): it allows old versions
	- pragma solidity^0.4.23 (RegistryExec.sol#18): it allows old versions
	- pragma solidity^0.4.23 (RegistryExec.sol#29): it allows old versions
	- pragma solidity^0.4.23 (RegistryExec.sol#253): it allows old versions

vulnerability_findings.name: low-level-calls
vulnerability_findings.message:
Low level call in RegistryExec.exec (RegistryExec.sol#282-311):
	-address(app_storage).call.value(msg.value)(abi.encodeWithSelector(EXEC_SEL,msg.sender,_exec_id,_calldata)) == false RegistryExec.sol#294-302

vulnerability_findings.name: low-level-calls
vulnerability_findings.message:
Low level call in RegistryExec.updateAppInstance (RegistryExec.sol#415-457):
	-address(app_storage).call(abi.encodeWithSelector(EXEC_SEL,inst.current_provider,_exec_id,abi.encodeWithSelector(UPDATE_INST_SEL,inst.app_name,inst.version_name,inst.current_registry_exec_id))) == false RegistryExec.sol#424-438

vulnerability_findings.name: low-level-calls
vulnerability_findings.message:
Low level call in RegistryExec.updateAppExec (RegistryExec.sol#469-490):
	-address(app_storage).call(abi.encodeWithSelector(EXEC_SEL,msg.sender,_exec_id,abi.encodeWithSelector(UPDATE_EXEC_SEL,_new_exec_addr))) == false RegistryExec.sol#475-485

vulnerability_findings.message:
The arithmetic operator can overflow.
It is possible to cause an integer overflow or underflow in the arithmetic operation. 
Classification: SWC-101

vulnerability_findings.name: Multiple Calls in a Single Transaction (SWC 113)
vulnerability_findings.message:
Multiple calls are executed in the same transaction.
This call is executed following another call within the same transaction. It is possible that the call never gets executed if a prior call fails permanently. This might be caused intentionally by a malicious callee. If possible, refactor the code such that each transaction only executes one external call or make sure that all callees can be trusted (i.e. they’re part of your own codebase).
Classification: SWC-113

vulnerability_findings.name: Exception State (SWC 110)
vulnerability_findings.message:
An assertion violation was triggered.
It is possible to trigger an assertion violation. Note that Solidity assert() statements should only be used to check invariants. Review the transaction trace generated for this issue and either make sure your program logic is correct, or use require() instead of assert() if your goal is to constrain user inputs or enforce preconditions. Remember to validate inputs from both callers (for instance, via passed arguments) and callees (for instance, via return values).
Classification: SWC-110
